src:
Iz morja potegnili konjak iz prve svetovne vojne
07 Nov 2019, 17:26 by STA

Skupina švedskih strokovnjakov je iz Baltskega morja potegnila več sto steklenic konjaka in zeliščnega likerja, ki so bile natovorjene na ladji Kyros in jo je med prvo svetovno vojno leta 1917 potopila nemška podmornica. Tovor je bil namenjen v tedanjo carsko Rusijo.



Fotografija je simbolična. Foto: Pixabay

STOCKHOLM > Skupina Ocean X, ki se je specializirala za reševanje alkohola iz razbitin, je ob tem po poročanju francoske tiskovne agencije AFP sporočila, da preverjajo, ali je alkohol še primeren za pitje.
Skupini je uspelo rešiti 600 steklenic konjaka in 300 steklenic zeliščnega likerja benediktinca. Konjak je iz destilarne De Haartman, ki danes več ne obstaja. Tako konjak kot benediktinca sedaj testirajo v laboratoriju. Nato pa nameravajo te steklenice prodati na dražbi v kakšni od avkcijskih hiš.
“Razmere v Baltskem morju so zelo primerne za hrano tovrstne pijače, saj je tam temno in mrzlo,” je dejal vodja odprave Peter Lindberg.
Kyros je iz Švedske odplula maja 1917. Nemška podmornica jo je potopila v Alandskem morju. Posadka je preživela in so jo rešili na drugo ladjo. Kasneje se je vrnila na Švedsko.
Lindberg je dejal, da je njegova skupina razbitino odkrila pred skoraj 20 leti, a so nato izgubili položaj ladje. Kasneje jim je uspelo, da so razbitine ponovno našli na globini 77 metrov v Alandskem morju med Švedsko in Finsko. Čiščenje razbitine, preden so jo lahko prvič preiskali potapljači, je trajalo več let. Oceanu X je pri dvigu steklenic na površje pomagalo podjetje s podvodnimi vozili na daljinsko upravljanje.
text:
World War I Cognac pulled from the sea
07 Nov 2019, 17:26 by STA

A team of Swedish experts pulled hundreds of bottles of cognac and herbal liqueur from the Baltic Sea, loaded on a Kyros ship and sunk by a German submarine during World War I in 1917. The cargo was destined for the then imperial Russia.



Photography is symbolic. Photo credit: Pixabay

STOCKHOLM> The Ocean X group, which specializes in dealing with alcohol from the wreckage, said AFP reported that they were still drinking.
The group managed to salvage 600 bottles of cognac and 300 bottles of Benedictine herbal liqueur. The cognac is from the De Haartman Distillery, which no longer exists today. Both Cognac and Benedictine are now being tested in the laboratory. Then they plan to auction these bottles at one of the auction houses.
"The situation in the Baltic Sea is well suited to this type of food because it is dark and cold there," said expedition manager Peter Lindberg.
Kyros sailed from Sweden in May 1917. A German submarine sank it in the Åland Sea. The crew survived and were rescued to another ship. She later returned to Sweden.
Lindberg said his group discovered the wreck nearly 20 years ago, but then lost the position of the ship. They later managed to find the wreckage again at a depth of 77 meters in the Åland Sea between Sweden and Finland. It took several years for the wreck to be cleaned before it could be searched by divers. Ocean X was aided by a remote control underwater vehicle company to lift the bottles.
